  • Description: DRIVER BROUGHT PACKAGE TO DAMAGE MATERIAL TABLE. IT WAS BAGGED IMMEDIATEDLY UPON DISCOVERING A LEAK. RESPONDER PROCESSED IT AND A MINIMAL AMOUNT WAS SPILLED. THE GALLON CONTAINER WAS DAMAGED/BENT. A SEAM ON THE BOTTOM OF THE METAL CONTAINER OPENED, RELEASING THE CONTENTS.

item.title: Report E-2025020412
item.description:
Report E-2025020412

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-26
  • City: LOXLEY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated (150) gallons of material released from one (1) 330-gallon plastic tote punctured by a forklift. Clean Harbors personnel observed that the released material impacted 30 ft-by-30 ft area of dock floor concrete. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerized them into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The remaining material in the product tote was to be transferred to a new 330-gallon IBC tote. However, both pumps cleaned harbors brought were faulty. They had obtained a functional pump from a local supplier and began pumping out the material. Work was paused to obtain upgraded PPE. After obtaining the correct PPE, personnel were able to complete the tote transfer. The incident generated a total of six (6) containers. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum contains two (2) 330-gallon poly tote bladders (cut up), Poly sheeting, and PPE. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum contains a diaphragm pump rinse water. One (1) 330-gallon tote contains the original product. Three (3) 55-gallon poly drums contain absorbent debris. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020318
item.description:
Report E-2025020318

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-15
  • City: MONTGOMERY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 15th, 2025, at 18:00 hours, personnel in the CSXT Montgomery, Alabama Yard discovered GATX 53808, a loaded tank car of Terpene Hydrocarbons NOS, leaking from the manway. The car was isolated and the shipper, Kraton Chemicals, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 20250215-00065). Marion Environmental, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the manway cover gasket improperly installed- allowing product to release from the car. Contractor personnel replaced the manway cover gasket and decontaminated the exterior of the car. Following securement of the car it was released for transportation. The issues identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Gerri Sage).

item.title: Report I-2025030028
item.description:
Report I-2025030028

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-10
  • City: Calvert
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS TRANSPORTATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver went to fill 6,800 gallon tank, and gauge said that it had room for 4,000 gallons. He knew he had just under 4,000 on his truck, but was not going to try to force it in. He stopped to blow out the lines just before the gauge hit 400 gallons left but it started to overflow. He had a loss of containment of about 30 gallons of ferric chloride by the time he blew out his lines. 100% went into containment. When he was done, the tank still read it had 400 gallons until full, indicating that the customer's tank gauge was not working properly. No Exposure Injuries.
